content: The words included at the top of William Charles' political cartoon "A Scene on the Frontiers as practiced by "humane" British and their worthy allies" are meant to provide context and to emphasize the message being conveyed by the image. The words read: "A Scene on the frontiers as practiced by "humane" British and their worthy allies." The words in quotes, "humane" British, are meant to be ironic, as the cartoon depicts a brutal and inhumane act being committed by the British and their Native American allies. The words are intended to highlight the hypocrisy of the British, who claimed to be civilized and humane, but in reality, were supporting violence and cruelty against American settlers. The words serve to convey the cartoonist's perspective on the conflict and to criticize the actions of the British and their allies.
